When it was discovered that some cosmological theories and observations by astrophysicists gave an age for the universe, and theories of stellar evolution and observations by astronomers gave an older age for the universe, this was a mystery. All the evidence points to a universe that expanded from a hot, dense state, although here there are several competing theories for the earliest stages. That the universe was old has not been in question, not for over a hundred years. The theories made predictions that have been born out in observation.
 
 It was always known that the theories were not yet complete, that they could, and would have to be modified, as new data came in. This is the nature of science. Ursus maritimus

Actually Copenricus and Galileo got rid of the old system because it didn't explain all the movements of planets etc, in relation to earth.

 They got rid of it because of conceptual complications -- to get better accuracies, more and more "additions" (epicycles, quadrants, and the like) had to be arbitrarily added. And the sizes of the epicycles and rotational speeds had to be arbitrarily adjusted to account for the actual observations. The simplest heliocentric model of Copernicus was already extremely accurate without any adjustments. There was a bit of "aesthetics" involved -- because a very simple model was very accurate, it, well, felt right.
 
 
 
Why do you think Copernicus' system was taken up? When do you propose that it became 'more accurate' than the geocentric system?

 It became more accurate when Kepler, who already accepted the heliocentric model, discovered his three laws of planetary motion:
 planets actually travel in ellipses about the sun, with the sun at one of the foci;
 a given planet "sweeps equal areas in equal times" in its orbit;
 and the ratio of the square of the semimajor axis to the cube of the planets period (or is it the cube of the semimajor axis to the square of the period) is the same constant for all planets.
 
 Once these laws became understood, it was possible to very accurately calculate the orbits of the planets. And, once Newton, who already accepted Kepler's model despite some small inaccuracies, discovered universal gravitation and could calculate the perturbations on the orbits by the other planets, these small inaccuracies were accounted for.
 
 And when, no matter how hard people tried, the observations of the orbit of Uranus could not be reconciled with the calculations, Newton's laws were not abandoned -- instead a new planet was hypothesized and eventually Neptune was discovered.
 
 And when the calculations of the orbits of the moons of Jupiter could not be reconciled with the observations, Newton's laws were not abandoned. Instead, it was hypothesized that the speed of light was finite, and allowance was made for this fact.
 
 The point is, there are almost always some discrepencies to any scientific theory. You do not usually just throw out a theory just because of discrepencies. You try to resolve them, either by making more accurate observations, or by making adjustments to the theory.
